I was initially skeptical about this game before I played it. I wasn't even sure about buying it, as the whole portal gun and portals concept seemed unusual to me, even though I enjoy science fiction. I was wrong. The humor and voice acting in this game are phenomenal. They're not cheesy, although it's occasionally cheesy. Each of the story's characters has their own distinct sense of humor. The different characters truly have distinct personalities. The level design is just fantastic. By the way, I never played the first Portal game. One of these days, I'm planning to play it if I can spare the time. I wouldn't have played it if I hadn't played the sequel.

Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember watching the ever-irksome Timmy Mallet for the five-minute Transformers cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others are back, and instantly recognizable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound effects are there. Graphically, the cell-shaded presentation is perfect, and very, very Generation One. But aside from that, it's actually a very fun game. The combat mechanics are extremely well-done. Transforming mid-fight is often a necessity, and seamlessly woven into combos, making it quite unlike the excellent War for Cybertron games. Another distinction is the heavy focus on melee combat, but some enemies (e.g., Seekers) require a switch to a ranged blaster.

I downloaded the game and played it for a bit, but it was underwhelming. I spent more time trying to log in than actually playing the game. There's a bug where it prompts you to update the terms of service, but clicking 'accept' doesn't work, so you have to restart the client. That's not ideal, but what I find concerning is that I'm forced to link my Steam and GFACE accounts. They claim it's for DLC, but I'm not sure why that's necessary, especially since it's not reversible. Now I know that a company I don't care about has access to my Steam information. The game itself is somewhat disappointing. It's easily recognizable as a Call of Duty clone, but somehow they managed to make the gunplay worse. It's hard to fathom how they achieved that.

4K+ at 60fps (GTX 970) and dual audio options, along with Neptune Gear, make for a fantastic experience. What's not to love? (Check out the excellent port in this YouTube video  https //www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo.) This game is a great entry point for newcomers to the series. Keep in mind that there is some (skippable) dialogue. As usual, I recommend using a gamepad, but I had no issues with a keyboard-mouse setup, which is fully rebindable. The price is reasonable, and I wouldn't have been disappointed with a purchase. Plus, more than half the DLC is included for free, providing plenty to play with. I highly recommend this game to JRPG, anime, and visual novel fans, as long as you're comfortable with occasional breaks between action sequences. Cheers. (No commentary playlist available here  https //www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1.)

I experienced no performance issues at release, and after all these patches, the game plays really well. In my opinion, this is a truly great and fun game, although the format may be somewhat annoying (where the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies every time you progress the story). I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments, where you can play Batman alongside one more character, and the ability to use the controller for most parts of the game, but the mouse and keyboard for the tank combat segments was greatly appreciated. Driving the Batmobile around the free-roam city, including when chasing the APC commanders, is actually quite enjoyable once you master the art of using the breaks to skid around corners, and when you master that, driving around the city is really quite enjoyable.

Overall, the game is a fantastic FPS shooter. The graphics, sound, and gameplay are all top-notch - great mechanics, engaging story, memorable characters, and a fantastic voice acting, along with a killer soundtrack. However, it's not for the faint of heart, as some of the cutscenes can be quite graphic and intense. Despite this, it's hard to overlook the flaws when the game is this good, and I noticed a few issues  no SLI support, which made the game run poorly on my old dual-GPU GTX 590. Make sure to have a decent single-GPU card to play this game smoothly.

Although English is not my native language, I'm Dutch, so please bear with any minor typing or grammatical mistakes in my review of this fantastic game. I will break down this review into several categories  graphics, controls, sound, and replayability. Graphics  the game features a comic-like style, with very slick and detailed visuals. The graphics can be set to 'high' without putting a strain on your system. I run this game on an i5 Pentium processor with an NVIDIA GeForce 710M card, 8GB of memory, and Windows 8.1, and it runs smoothly. Controls  the game can be played with a keyboard and mouse, but it's also compatible with an Xbox controller.

I'm two hours into this game and I'm dying from laughter. The gameplay is solid, the art design is beautiful, the music is surprisingly high-quality and fitting, and the story/world has me hooked. But the best part about this game is the comedy. If you've played any RPGs since the dawn of video game RPGs, you'll laugh at the various jokes, parodies, and references; if you've never played an RPG before, you'll still enjoy the game for its humor. If you played Final Fantasy 7 or X, you absolutely need to play this game, without giving away too much... I had to stop playing after two hours to give my cheeks a break from laughing and smiling so much. What a delight so far.

I'm truly sorry to say, but I tried to be supportive of free-to-play games and indie developers, but I didn't really enjoy this game. The description sounded right up my alley, but the execution fell short of my expectations. I love puzzle and exploration games, but I found this game to be completely unintuitive, and even after looking up how to progress, I still didn't find the gameplay itself enjoyable. It also lacks a pause button, or if it does have one, I never found it. Considering that a lot of sequences in the game are timed, this seems like a critical oversight. I also feel like this game is a lot more cutscene than it is game, and I end up just sitting around drumming my fingers a lot.

This game was an absolute delight from start to finish. It was a truly captivating experience, from the story to the graphics, I was completely hooked. The story wasn't just a narrative, but it felt like I was the protagonist, trying to figure out what came next in the story that my character was sharing. Gameplay was excellent, and I learned a lot about myself through this game (mainly about my fear of heights, which I never had a problem with until the ice caverns). My stomach churned the whole time, but I persisted for Uncle Fred! If you guys were to create a DLC or sequel, I would be the first to buy it and recommend it to everyone I know. Thank you to everyone involved in making this, you created an absolutely beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization Beyond Earth is a turn-based game where you build your civilization to a certain goal or 'victory'. In previous games, you were set on the Earth's timeline, progressing through eras like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and the Modern Age. In this game, you're set in the future, on a mission to colonize a new planet. What I enjoy about this game is that it took a new approach to the game, introducing mechanics such as the Affinity System and Orbital Layer. However, I didn't find it enjoyable that the new mechanics sometimes made the game overwhelming. To improve this game, I think they could incorporate some new artwork, such as the environment you experience when communicating with another leader.

This game is a great experience, offering tons of replayability and immense fun as a zombie survival game. In my top five zombie games ever played, I can honestly say that this is one of the better, more realistic zombie games I've ever played. It's very much designed like a survival horror, as you must conserve your ammo, heal your own wounds when you're injured, take medication when you're infected, and so on. Additionally, I find the zombies to be very naturally animated, making them feel like a free-to-play game. I recommend playing with one or two friends, as the community is super friendly, and you can usually make friends or communicate with others in the chat or voice chat.

Unfortunately, I cannot thoroughly recommend or enjoy this game due to the short time I've played it, as I know I would be addicted if it didn't have the following two game-breaking issues. Firstly, the lack of Australian servers puts players at a severe disadvantage, causing unbearable lag. Moreover, the offline training mode stuttered and lagged as well, which is astonishing. Additionally, the poor ping and lag ruin the game. Furthermore, the game's assets, such as the menus, backgrounds, and in-game graphics, are buggy and erratic. I've never experienced this level of lag with this graphics card before, and I thought it might not be compatible with my overclocked settings. However, setting my GPU back to stock settings did not resolve the issue.

I recently completed the game, finishing it late last night. Although the story may not be particularly deep or captivating, the narrative shines through its engaging storytelling. The atmosphere is rich and immersive, with the many collectibles doing an excellent job of fleshing it out. I learned a lot about the world of Batman, which was a bit disappointing given the scarcity of boss battles. However, there are certainly more games in the future that will rectify this. The combat is moderately challenging, but leans towards the easier side. Leveling up Batman wasn't particularly satisfying, but the gadgets and upgrades you acquire during the campaign add a pleasant new layer of gameplay mechanics. Gaining access to previously inaccessible areas creates a sense of accomplishment and progression.

To the moon is no mere game; nay, it's a veritable experience, and it was one of the best of my life at that. Telltale's The Walking Dead is sad? Ho ho ho! Well, it's no match for a trip to the moon! Never before have I been so depressed yet fulfilled over something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling in my opinion, and the soundtrack is a gorgeously charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls are a bit finicky, and the gameplay is not the strong point, but the story is so fantastic that I did not care one bit. Plus, the humor is great, and it definitely doesn't intrude upon the distinguished nature of the story. And the references to the doctor are endless.

Bastion is a bloody brilliant game, boasting a rich and engaging storyline. Following a catastrophic event, you begin to rebuild within the bastion. The game offers a vast array of choices, allowing you to select the perfect combination of buildings, weapons, and power-ups to give you a strategic advantage. The art style and music in the game are both fantastic, creating a visually stunning experience that brings the apocalypse to life. Moreover, the game features a dynamic narration system, which responds to your actions in real-time. For instance, if you pick up a weapon and then switch to another in the armory, the narration will acknowledge your decision and adapt accordingly.

I initially purchased this game during its early development phase, when the primary currency was spacebux and the tech tree was not yet established. At that time, the game was still in its early stages, and all the weapons were equally overpowered, which eliminated any balance issues; anyone could take out anyone at any moment. Additionally, the game used to provide unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You might expect that a game with an extensive arsenal of 'bajillions of guns' would offer more than six weapon slots and three loadouts before requiring additional purchases. In reality, I had around three pages worth of guns and was planning on exploring more ideas for future additions, as I found the game's gunplay to be a significant source of enjoyment.

This game was a delightful surprise. I often come across rave reviews of certain products that are often misleading. In this case, the reviews reflect the fun of this charming little game. It's an intriguing blend between a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA, and it pulls it off with style. I found myself enjoying characters that I wouldn't typically enjoy in other MOBA games. I had expected this trait to continue, but decided to give a melee tank a try anyway. I was pleasantly surprised with the outcome and ended up trying out more as they were unlocked from playing games. The art style and interface is quaintly charming. As such, I now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper from creating a card set for the game.

I've just started playing, and I'm thoroughly enthralled by this game. I put on my headphones and become completely absorbed in the game for hours at a time. It's been a while since a game has had this level of impact on me. The music perfectly sets the mood, the sound effects are spot-on, and the controls are seamless. I eagerly anticipate every combat, and they've expertly optimized the combat to an extremely high level. I initially had doubts about the naval combat system, but it's surprisingly enjoyable to unleash destruction on multiple fleets at once! The only way to lose in this game is to fail to retreat. If the combat appears overwhelming, simply regroup, and counter-attack. Thank you to the developers for crafting an incredible gaming experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has brought about many changes for the series, particularly for its protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original series may be upset at the change to their beloved character, it's certainly for the better; and this new game by Ninja Theory proves it. The game serves as the perfect point for newcomers to jump into the series. It shows the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante, and it chronicles his journey from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout, the game weaves a clear, narrative arc for the new Dante, making him a compelling character to watch. The story follows Dante as he's introduced into the corrupt world he willfully chose to ignore.

Where do I start on this absolutely captivating game? Its story is absolutely charming, with a wealth of detail woven throughout. It's a bundle of joy, bad puns, and endearing characters, including annoying dogs and hidden secrets. While it tackles serious themes, it's not afraid to inject humor and lighthearted moments. The character design is spot on, with a diverse cast of characters each with their own distinct personalities and secrets. One of the standout features is the absence of combat, which sets it apart from other RPGs. Drawing inspiration from Earthbound, one of the best RPGs I've seen, it's clear that this game is going to be exceptional. The soundtrack is also one of the most memorable I've ever heard, and it's easy to see why.

I'm recommending this game solely because it's free, and it might provide a more enjoyable experience for others. As for my experience, the game didn't resonate with me. Half the story relies heavily on shock value. I wasn't shocked or emotionally moved in any way by this. Perhaps I'm desensitized, or maybe it was too simplistic to evoke a reaction from me. The other half of the game attempts to paint a vivid picture of a person's mental decline. It explores themes such as obsession, hallucinations, depression, and a few other issues. In theory, it's an intriguing concept. However, the game took me 10 minutes to complete, and that's with reading and digesting every piece of information I could absorb.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game that presents a concept and then gets out of your way. It's an engaging way to test your mind while still being fun. Although this game may not be as story-heavy as others, it gave birth to one of the most popular games of 2011. I still play this game when I'm feeling bored, and I love to come back and see what gave rise to a legend and what is a legend. Gameplay  Portal's gameplay is relatively simple, to explain at least. You use portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate a part of the puzzle. Two buttons are in the game, one that you press and one that you need a cube to place on.

If you can overlook the minor bugs, which I personally only encountered two  one minor and the other quite annoying, the edit resolved both issues, resulting in a significant increase in my FPS from 60-90 to 80-120. If you're looking for a space exploration game, I can definitely recommend this. Since most of these reviews focus on specs, I'll include mine  i5-6600K, Radeon RX480 (~200€), Z170 Pro - Gaming (~150€), 16GB DDR4 RAM (~70€), and a total cost of ~650€, which is well within the medium price range. While this rig is relatively new, I can confidently say that I experienced almost constant 60+ FPS on high settings with vsync enabled, which is impressive, considering 90% of the comments claim to be rocking an overkill setup and only achieving 20 FPS.

Remember the age of mythology? Indeed, it's been a while since there's been an RTS game of such high quality. Divinity  Dragon Commander comes close to the borders of my personal favorite RTS games. Combine this with a grand strategy mode and it hits the spot. I'm not (read  I'm not biased) overly enthusiastic due to the fact that this game allows you to transform into a dragon, supporting your troops by providing aid, attacking, and even commanding unit production, direction, and spawning simultaneously. Honestly, I do like the complex RTS games nowadays. Think of Civilization V and similar titles. However, such games often attempt to cram complex mechanics, charts, and resources into one intricate game mode.

Undertale comes together to create something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics, a nod to the retro title, and the music, a perfect accompaniment, harmonize to create truly beautiful and impactful moments. The script effortlessly runs the gamut from comedic to dramatic to heart-wrenching to hopeful, sometimes all at once, and does this while subverting RPG tropes and turning them on their head. Without delving into the world, characters, story, or gameplay, I could write pages about it. But I'll keep it brief  if you're a fan of RPGs, play this game. If you're a gamer, play this game. If you have seven free hours between now and your mortality, take the time to play this game.

I've had this game for only a few months, but in that short time, two DLCs have emerged, along with patches that have transformed an already excellent game into an even better one. The developers are extremely active in the community, which is evident in the various discussion forums and dev diaries. While there's a steep learning curve to the game's mechanics, I'm still learning, the breadth of strategy allows for a multitude of ways to achieve goals and capitalize on certain situations. In my opinion, the game is almost infinitely replayable, and I find myself fully immersed in every session I play, regardless of how the play-through goes.

Warframe is an enjoyable game for the initial few hours of play. However, after those hours, you'll likely find that the game's offerings become repetitive, with the combat, enemies, and gameplay becoming the primary focus. The one notable highlight is that the developers are dedicated to regularly releasing updates, which often include significant changes, new Warframes, and other improvements. While it's a decent game to play casually, it may not hold your interest beyond a few months unless you're a dedicated grinder. On the plus side, the game is free, so I recommend giving it a try. If you're looking for a quick fix, it's definitely worth a shot.

This game is incredibly dull. I had high hopes for it, thinking it was a PC version of 'Katamari Damacy', a popular and enjoyable PS2 game. Unfortunately, it falls short of that standard. In this game, you collect and absorb increasingly larger objects to grow bigger and absorb even larger ones. However, the gameplay isn't as seamless as it could be, the levels lack creativity and the content is a surreal horror show. I don't mean an entertaining horror show, but one that leaves you feeling somewhat depressed and questioning the meaning of life. Every 'living' creature in this game, from small pets to human beings, raises the question of whether the creators of this game had an interest in taxidermy.

Alright, let me explain a few things. As someone deeply interested in politics, I was very intrigued when I first heard about this game. I thought, 'Oh wow, a simulator of the road to becoming president! That sounds fun!' Unfortunately, it wasn't as exciting as I expected. The game starts off by asking you to choose a side  Republican or Democrat, with no independent or third-party option. A bit disappointed, I still remained optimistic, so I continued to see what I could do. I will give the game credit, the character customization, although limited, is quite enjoyable to mess around with. It's the only time it's an option to wear your head or not in a campaign, literally.

My stats (at the time of writing this review)  8.6 hours to reach the end, 10 collectibles found out of 25, zero achievements out of 15. What I liked  The visuals up until the last level (Ice Caves) were impressive. The story is not that great, but the ending (after the closing credits) left a somewhat positive impression, making me not regret the time I spent playing this game. What I disliked  The visuals in the last level were underwhelming, and the gameplay in the last level became frustrating due to the repetition of tasks, making it feel like I had to repeat the same actions multiple times before getting it right. Additionally, the achievements were too challenging, with only 2.1% of players achieving less than 13 out of 15.

Pros  +graphic Cons  -bugs (especially environmental, you may get stuck or your shots may hit an invisible wall, despite having a clear line of sight of the enemy) -handheld game babysitting -dumb AI -enemies always seem to know where you are when you're spotted -godlike accuracy by the enemy, which is frustrating, like the first Ghost Warrior. -terrible checkpoints and saves. -boring story that I couldn't care less about; I won't recommend it unless it's 90% off, even then I find playing this game to be an extremely boring chore, just playing for the sake of finishing it to move on to the next game in my library. Considering the time I wasted on the first Ghost Warrior (which was equally boring, and I feel liberated when I finished it), I probably won't play it until the end.

Review for November 29, 2015  Do not buy this game, as the servers are offline. You can't play. Don't waste your money on this game. I could play it, and I enjoyed it, but it's not worth it. As the song goes, 'Go on, take the money and run, uh, uh, uh, uh!' It's an hour-long game, and it's awesome! Some guns are overpowered, and the matchmaking can be unfair, but hey, at least it's better than Battlefield 3's matchmaking. As a newbie, it's tough to find a fair match, especially with higher-level players who aren't even human - they just camp and shoot you in the face without any consequences.

It's not difficult for me to see why others enjoy this game, but it wasn't for me. One reason is that I have a preference for larger-scale games and I'm more interested in playing games with controllers. Additionally, the game's vast universe is awe-inspiring, but I found that same scale hindered my enjoyment. The steep learning curve and the time it took to do anything engaging at the beginning were too great for me. Perhaps if I were more patient and had more time for gaming, this might have been more compelling. However, I don't have the luxury of time, and there are many other VR games I'd rather spend my time on.

My favorite first-person shooter of all time is a game that requires precision and strategy. Run-and-gun playstyles don't apply here. The recoil and ballistics are realistic, and single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons usually result in death unless they just graze you. Rounds drop over distance and short, controlled bursts are necessary to remain on target. There's no magical ammunition pool, so it's crucial to conserve your shots. If you reload halfway through your magazine, you'll end up with a pouch full of half-full mags. You can't keep sprinting forever, as your aim will suffer if you're not careful. Take a moment to rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill to steady your aim. In this game, accuracy suffers when standing.

I'd like to start by stating that I didn't purchase EU at its initial release and instead acquired it on sale, which included EU, so I never experienced the issues some users claimed to have encountered. I thoroughly enjoyed the game, although it was unforgiving in its early stages, but rewarding when I got things right. As for XCOM 2, I'm a big fan of it; the game runs smoothly on my medium settings with a GTX 560 and 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game was set to high and it ran a bit sluggishly, but not to the point of being unplayable. However, when I dropped it down to medium, it smoothed out. I'm not sure if I'm just fortunate when it comes to encountering issues with games or what, but it seems that most of the negative reviews seem to be coming from some rather entitled individuals.

This game offers a wide variety of ship types, with physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missiles. It's easy to learn resource management, and the game has a dark humored, non-grindy feel, especially if you utilize the civvy station types. However, it's not without its drawbacks - the AI teammates can be subpar, and there's a limited variety of equipment types and leveling skills, which don't branch out. Despite these minuses, the game still offers some variety and strategy to be had. It starts off quickly and maintains a steady pace. Although there's a limited selection of equipment, it still feels like there's always another ship to unlock or skill to level up. To increase the game's longevity, mods are the way to go. The fight for universe is easily the star, but the big fight for beef is also very good.

World leaders are gathering in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). Over 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe are arriving for a five-day meeting. The agenda will cover issues such as China's economic power and Iraq's future after this Sunday's elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the more than 20 government leaders and heads of state attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the WE Forum are expected to be muted. Anti-globalization campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. The Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, scheduled to run in parallel with the WE Forum's more exclusive event in Davos.

Deadline approaches for Fiat-GM deal  Fiat and General Motors (GM) have until midnight on February 1 to resolve their disagreement over a potential takeover. The deadline marks the point at which Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM, part of an alliance agreed upon in 2000. GM, whose European operations are currently losing money, no longer wishes to own the unprofitable Fiat unit. Reports of stalled talks sent Fiat shares down 1.2% on Tuesday, following a 4% gain on Monday after hopes of a settlement. The US firm is reportedly offering around $2 billion (£1.06 billion) to extricate itself from the arrangement. It has argued that the deal was voided by Fiat's decision to sell off its finance arm and halve GM's stake through a capital-raising effort. The 2000 deal was the result of a race between GM and DaimlerChrysler to ally with Fiat.

Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has criticized the Iraq War, stating that the billions of pounds spent on the conflict in Iraq and the Middle East should have been used to reduce poverty. The head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales made the comments on BBC Radio 4 and will reiterate his stance in his Christmas Midnight Mass. In his Christmas message, the cardinal denounced the war in Iraq as a "terrible" waste of money. He and the Archbishop of Canterbury have both spoken out against the war. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day slot, the cardinal criticized the fact that "billions" have been spent on war, instead of being used to bring people "out of dire poverty, malnutrition, and disease." The cardinal hopes that 2005 will be a year of campaigning to "make history and end poverty.

British stars had their major Oscar hopes dashed as UK stars failed to win acting and directing prizes, despite receiving three nominations. Mike Leigh's Vera Drake failed to take the director or screenplay awards, and Imelda Staunton was overlooked for the best actress prize. Kate Winslet lost to Hilary Swank for best actress, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okenedo failed to win the best supporting actor awards. However, Andrea Arnold, who presented children's television shows Number 73 and Motormouth in the 1980s, won the short film award for her gritty drama Wasp. Arnold described the experience as "totally overwhelming." Wasp tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, outshining films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Debra Hill, a renowned screenwriter and producer, best known for her work on the 1970s horror classic Halloween, has passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film Halloween, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, the film grossed over $60 million worldwide, a record for an independent film at that time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on Escape from New York and The Fog. Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way up the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before partnering with Carpenter. She was widely regarded as a trailblazing woman in the film industry, taking on roles in the 1970s that were more commonly held by men.

According to a report by UK think-tank Demos, a quarter of broadband users in Britain regularly upload content and maintain personal websites, which is encouraging more people to express themselves online. Research suggests that having an always-on, fast internet connection is transforming the way people use the internet. Over five million households in the UK have broadband, and this number is growing rapidly. A report by Demos looked at the impact of broadband on people's online habits, finding that more than half of those with broadband log on to the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the web. Significantly, the report argues that broadband is encouraging people to take a more active role online.

Yukos, heading back to US courts, Russian oil and gas company Yukos is due in a US court on Thursday as it continues to fight for its survival. The firm is in the process of being broken up by Russian authorities in order to pay a $27 billion (£14 billion) tax bill. Yukos has filed for bankruptcy in the US, hoping to use international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yugasnkneftegas. The unit was, however, sold for $9.4 billion to state oil firm Rosneft, but only after the state auction had been disrupted. Yukos lawyers now say the auction violated US bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to go after any company that buys its assets, using all and every legal means.

Voters are flocking to the blog awards website to cast their ballots in the annual Bloggies, which recognizes the best weblogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that it was temporarily closed due to an overwhelming number of visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a remarkable year, with the term "blog" being named the word of the year by a top US dictionary in 2004. According to Technorati, a blog search engine, it tracks about six million blogs and notes that more than 12,000 new ones are added daily. Interestingly, a new blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to a Pew Internet and American Life research study, although less than 40% of the total blogs are updated at least once every two months.

Chinese state-owned firm 'Defies Beijing' is refusing to comply with a government order to halt construction of one of its giant dams, the Chinese state press has reported. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam is continuing work on the Xiluodu Dam, according to the Beijing News. The Xiluodu Dam is one of 30 large-scale construction projects ordered to be halted due to a lack of proper environmental assessments. The Beijing News reported that the company may instead opt to pay a fine. The firm has also disregarded orders to cease construction at two other projects - the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant. So far, 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for failing to conduct mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with its shutdown order.

Manchester United reduced Chelsea's Premier League lead to nine points after a scrappy victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney met Gary Neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which went in via a deflection off Richard Dunne, to put United ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne hooked a volley over David James' head and into his own net. Steve McManaman wasted City's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes, United had looked unlikely to earn the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching Chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more laboured than patient, and they managed to fashion just one chance - a Paul Scholes header over the bar.

Wales must learn health lessons, says new health minister Dr. Brian Gibbons, who has taken over the role following Jane Hutt's departure. On his first full day in office, Dr. Gibbons acknowledged "big challenges" in tackling waiting lists, but emphasized that the "essentials" are in place. However, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats called for policy changes. Meanwhile, Jane Hutt defended her record, attributing waiting times and lists to only 10% of the health agenda. Dr. Gibbons, a former GP in Blaengwynfi and Assembly Member for Aberavon, said NHS staff need a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform". One of the major issues that plagued Jane Hutt during her five-and-a-half years as the Assembly's first health minister was the length of waiting lists in Wales.

Ferguson hails Man United's resolve Manchester United's Alex Ferguson has praised his players' gutsy performance in the 1-0 win at Aston Villa. "That was our hardest away game of the season, and it was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with lots of good passing," said the Old Trafford boss. "We showed lots of character and guts, and we weren't going to lose. I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come, and Villa may have some players back when they do." Ferguson also hailed senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy came on and brought a bit of composure to the midfield, which we needed, and which no other player has got.

A documentary film about the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will be showcased at this year's Berlin Film Festival. The documentary, which will screen in the Panorama section, offers a candid look at the singer's career and personal life, from his early days in Wham! to more recent events. George Michael will introduce the screening on February 16 and will be joined by director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens. The 93-minute film explores the singer's early days in Wham! as well as his later career, including his legal battles with record label Sony and his stance against the Iraq War and American politics.

Downloads are now being included in the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of music downloads, previously only assigned to a separate download chart. Green Day's "Boulevard of Broken Dreams" is currently number two in Billboard's pop chart, and tops its digital chart. Download sales are set to be incorporated into the UK singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's hot digital sales chart. They will now be tallied with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up its new hot 100 chart. The second new chart, the pop 100, also combines airplay, digital and physical sales, but confines its airplay information to US radio stations that play chart music.

Scott Richter, the self-proclaimed spam king behind optinrealbig.com, is seeking bankruptcy protection as the company, which has sent billions of junk mail messages, faces legal battles, including a lawsuit from Microsoft, which is seeking millions of dollars in damages. Optinrealbig, listed as the third-largest spammer in the world by junk mail watchdog Spamhaus, was sued in December 2003 for sending messages that violated anti-spam laws. The company's legal woes have been exacerbated by its legal battles, with the filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy seen as a way to resolve its legal issues while still allowing it to continue trading.

Arnesen has denied any rumors suggesting that he denied coach Jacques Santini's departure due to a clash of personalities at Tottenham Hotspur. According to Arnesen, the only reason for Santini's resignation was his personal problems, which he has been dealing with. "It's absolutely not true," Arnesen told BBC Radio 5 Live. "There is only one thing that made him resign and that is his own personal problems. He has spoken to me recently and said this matter is absolutely for himself." Arnesen added that he was unable to shed any light on the issues that led to Santini's departure after just 13 games in charge. He emphasized, "Jacques has never gone into exactly what it was. But I trust him in that; you have to accept it. I think we should respect it.

Ireland maintained their six-nation grand slam ambitions with an impressive victory over Scotland at Murrayfield, securing an 8-0 lead. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by halftime. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed victory. After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to welcoming England to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will try to give their coach Matt Williams a first Six Nations victory when Italy comes to Edinburgh, but they struggled to turn pressure into points.

The economy will be at the heart of the election campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown said. Speaking after a cabinet meeting at No 10 Downing Street, he stated that voters will recognize that Labour has brought stability and growth, and will continue to do so. The parties have outlined their plans to tackle 'yob culture' and the Liberal Democrats have provided more details on their proposals to replace council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury wrote to all three parties, urging them not to turn the election into a competition about who can most effectively frighten voters about terrorism, asylum, and crime. He called on them not to turn the election into a competition about who can most effectively frighten voters about these issues.

Brizzel Brizzel will be one of eight Irish athletes competing in this weekend's AAA's championships in Sheffield. He will be defending his 200m title in the British trials. Joining him will be Alistair Cragg, who has been in tremendous form on the European circuit in recent weeks. Cragg is currently ranked number one in the world 200m ranking. Mark Carroll, another Irish athlete, will also be competing in the Europeans. He is ranked number three in the world 3000m ranking and will be hoping to confirm his place in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. James McIlroy, who has been in top form on the European circuit, will also be competing in the 800m event. He is one of the fastest 800m runners in the world this winter and is already assured of a place in Madrid.

Jason Robinson, a former rugby league international, has targeted dual-code success for England against Australia on Saturday. As a former rugby league international, Robinson has switched codes in 2000 and now leads England against Australia at Twickenham at 2 30 GMT. England have the chance to seal their third autumn international victory after successive wins over Canada and South Africa, as well as gaining revenge for June's 51-15 hammering by the Wallabies. Meanwhile, Great Britain could end 34 years of failure against Australia with victory at Elland Road.

Warning  Be cautious of a tsunami aid website claiming to collect donations on behalf of tsunami victims. The site appears authentic, as it uses an old version of the official disaster relief committee's webpage. However, it has no connection with the legitimate site and claims to have contacted the authorities about it. This is just the latest in a long list of scams that aim to capitalize on the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is contained in a spam email with a subject line reading "Urgent  Tsunami Earthquake Appeal" and a text that exhibits poor grammar and bad spelling, characteristic of many other phishing attempts.

Iraq's Ministry of Communications has invited bids for two telephone licenses, aiming to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. The ministry has invited local, Arab, and foreign companies to submit their bids. The successful bidder will partner with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry aims to increase Iraq's very low telephone service penetration rate from around 4.5% to about 25% within 10 years, also hoping to develop a highly visible and changeable telecommunications sector. The details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on February 9. Additionally, the ministry is planning a roadshow for investors in Amman, Jordan.

According to a two-year study, more women are taking charge of protecting their home computers from malicious net attacks, as the number of women buying programs to shield PCs from virus, spam, and spyware attacks rose by 11.2% each year between 2002 and 2004. The study, conducted by net security firm Preventon, reveals that security messages are reaching a diverse range of surfers. It is believed that 40% of those buying home net security programs are retired, a figure that has increased by an average of 13.2% over the last three years. Interestingly, more retired women (53%) are buying security software than retired men. The research reflects the evolving demographics of web users and growing awareness of the increased risks associated with high-speed broadband net connections for surfers.

Podcasting has revolutionized the way people consume music on their Apple iPods or other digital music players. With a storage capacity of up to 10,000 songs, it's no wonder that many podcasters are taking advantage of this space to fill. Led by former MTV host and VJ (video jockey) Adam Curry, podcasting has become a popular way for creators to produce and share their own audio content. The term 'podcasting' is derived from the Apple iPod, although it's not necessary to have an iPod to create or listen to a podcast. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show that podcasters produce, often from the comfort of their own homes. All they need is a microphone, a PC, and some editing software to create their shows, which they then upload to the internet, making them available for free download and listening.

Levy wins the Whitbread Novel Prize, and Andrea Levy has seen her book, 'Small Island', win the Whitbread Novel of the Year award. She is now a favourite to win the overall prize after beating Booker Prize winner Alan Hollinghurst's 'The Line of Beauty'. Geraldine McCaughren has picked up the children's fiction award for the third time for 'Not the End of the World'. All the category winners go through to compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which carries with it a £25,000 prize. A panel of judges, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant and writer Joanne Harris, will meet up on January 25 to decide the overall winner, with the announcement being made later that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has placed London-based Levy's novel as the 6/4 favourite to win.

Yukos seeks court action on sale Yukos will return to a US court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the little-known firm that has bought its main asset. Yukos has said it will sue Baikal and others involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas for $20 billion in damages. Yukos' US lawyers will attempt to have Baikal assets frozen after the Russian government ignored a US court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal's background and its motives for buying the unit are still unclear. Russian newspapers have claimed that Baikal, which bought the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4 billion (261 billion rubles, £4.8 billion) on Sunday at a state-provoked auction, has strong links with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-biggest oil producer.

Hearts 2-1 Livingston Hearts wrapped up their Scottish Cup quarter-final tie against Livingston with two goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller scored inside the opening 60 seconds, heading over Colin Meldrum and into the net from Jamie McAllister's free kick. McAllister himself scored the second when he met Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post to put the game beyond the visitors. Craig Easton headed in a controversial goal after an hour but Hearts held on. The opening goal came after Gus Bahoken had clumsily fouled Miller 35 yards from goal. McAllister floated the free kick into the Livi box and Miller outjumped the static visiting defense to loop his header from 10 yards over Meldrum. With just 10 minutes on the clock, the home side doubled their lead. Mikoliunas sprinted down the right, crossed to the back post where McAllister raced in to head past Meldrum.

Scotland's Justice Minister, Jamie Jamieson, has warned that she wants to take a tough stance against bigoted soccer fans, warning that she intends to ban them from matches "where it hurts the most" if they engage in sectarian behavior. This is part of a series of measures being considered by the Scottish government to tackle the issue of sectarianism. Jamieson praised Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in addressing the problem, emphasizing that stopping sectarian abuse associated with old firm matches is a key objective. The minister was speaking ahead of the third round of the Scottish Cup clash between Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The sectarianism long associated with sections of the support from both clubs has become a significant target for the executive. Last week, Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnie met with supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.

Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the British premiere of their new film, 'Beyond the Sea', at London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed and starred in the film, paying tribute to the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This is my tribute to someone I think was a remarkable talent," Spacey said, who, as Darin, sings all 18 songs on the film's soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife - real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I knew absolutely nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," Bosworth said, who attended the premiere with her British boyfriend, Orlando Bloom.

Leeds v Saracens (Friday) Headingley, 25 February 2000 GMT  The Tykes have brought in Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders on loan, while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Raphael Ibanez is named at hooker for Saracens in one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also selected in the pack, while Kevin Sorrell comes in at outside centre. Friday's game at Headingley got the go-ahead on Friday after passing an early pitch inspection. Leeds  Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. Replacements  Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMullan, Rock, Vickerman.

The future of the fixed line phone in your home could soon be an endangered species. Research by Nokia, a leading handset maker, shows that more and more people are using their mobile phone for every call they make or take. According to the study, over 45 million people in the UK, Germany, US, and South Korea now only use a mobile. The research found that people keep their fixed line phone because call charges are lower, but most of those questioned said the future is definitely mobile. The Nokia-sponsored study showed that mobiles and fixed phones were used for different purposes. Home phones were used for longer calls, but conversations on mobiles tended to be shorter, between mobiles and friends. In the UK, 69% of those questioned said they turned to their fixed phone because it was still cheaper to use than a mobile.

Jürgen Melzer delivered a stunning upset, defeating second-seeded Andre Agassi 6-3, 6-1 in the quarterfinals of the SAP Open. Agassi was frequently caught off guard by the Austrian's clever drop shots in San Jose. Meanwhile, defending champion and top seed Andy Roddick came from behind to beat Thomas Enqvist of Sweden 3-6, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5. Cyril Saulnier, an unseeded player, took down fourth-seeded Vincent Spadea 6-2, 6-4, while Tommy Haas overcame eighth-seeded Max Mirnyi 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-3), 6-2. Melzer has now beaten Agassi in two of their three meetings. "I had a solid game plan and executed it flawlessly," Melzer said. "It's always challenging to play against Andre.
