MPs to lords reform plan a group of MPs has tried to raise the pressure on Tony Blair over reform to the House of Lords by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party group has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber in which 70% of members would be elected. MPs and peers have failed to agree on reform since 1999 when 600 hereditaries lost their seats. The group says it can win support for removing the last 92 hereditaries. The government postponed plans to remove the remaining hereditary peers because they said they were unlikely to succeed after opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has argued that there needs to be consensus on reforms. There have been suggestions that there will be proposals for changing at least the powers of the Lords in Labour's manifesto.

Scott Allan Scott, 22, finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the José M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid, Spain. Although he was slightly disappointed with his run in the final, Scott is confident of winning a medal at the next European Indoor Championships. "It was definitely a learning curve, and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," the East Kilbride athlete said. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who equalled the Spanish record. Sweden's Robert Kronberg was second, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Scott won his heat in 7.64secs, but ran 0.04secs slower in his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix circuit final.

A US woman is suing Hewlett-Packard (HP) over claims that its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a certain date. The unnamed woman from Georgia alleges that a chip inside the cartridge tells the printer that it needs re-filling even when it does not. The lawsuit seeks to represent anyone in the US who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer firm, has declined to comment on the lawsuit. HP ink cartridges use a chip technology to sense when they are low on ink and advise the user to make a change. However, the suit claims the chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date regardless of whether they are empty.

Virgin Radio offers 3G broadcast UK broadcaster Virgin Radio says it will become the first station in the world to offer radio via 3G mobiles. The radio station, in partnership with technology firm Sydus, will broadcast on selected 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners will be able to download software from the Virgin website, which enables the service. James Cridland, head of new media at Virgin Radio, said  "It places radio at the heart of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will be the first station made available, followed by two digital stations, Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Mr. Cridland said  "This application will enable anyone, anywhere to listen to Virgin Radio simply with the phone in their pocket.

Roxy Music will appear at the Isle of Wight Music Festival in June, alongside Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. The band has already been confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, taking place from June 10-12. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzarek, Andy McKay, and Paul Thompson will take the stage on the Saturday night of the festival. Roxy Music is also working on new material, their first since the 1982 album Avalon. Formed in 1971 by Ferry, McKay, and Brian Eno, with Manzarek joining the following year, Roxy Music's first hit was 1972's 'Virginia Plain', with other hits including 'Street Life', 'Love is the Drug', and the 1981 John Lennon cover, 'Jealous Guy'.

Captains lining up for the aid match, Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll is one of four Six Nations captains included in the Northern Hemisphere squad for the IRB rugby aid match on March 5. France's Fabien Pelous, Gordon Bullock of Scotland and Italy's Marco Bortolami are also in the Northern party. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod Macqueen's Southern Hemisphere team in a tsunami fund-raising match at Twickenham. "I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players," he said. It will be a chance for Woodward to assess some of his options before unveiling his British and Irish Lions touring party, who will visit New Zealand in the summer. "The game promises to be a great spectacle," he said.

Spirit awards hail the comedy 'Sideways' as the standout winner of this year's independent spirit awards, sweeping all six of the awards for which it was nominated. The film was named best film, with Alexander Payne taking home the best director and best screenplay awards, along with his writing partner Jim Taylor. The film also won acting awards for stars Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. 'Sideways' is expected to make a strong showing at the Oscars, with a total of five nominations. The awards, now in their 20th year, honor films made outside the traditional studio system and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Other winners included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who took home the best actress award for her powerful performance as a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama 'Maria Full of Grace.' Moreno is also nominated for best actress at the Oscars. The best first screenplay award went to Joshua Marston for 'Maria Full of Grace'.

Prince, crowned the top music earner in 2004, surpassed even Madonna and Elton John on US magazine Rolling Stone's annual list, earning a whopping $56.5 million (approximately £30.4 million) from concerts, album, and publishing sales with his Musicology tour and album. He outshone Madonna, who came in second place, raking in $54.9 million (approximately £29.5 million) from her global re-invention tour. Simon and Garfunkel, industry veterans, placed tenth, earned $24.9 million (approximately £13.4 million) from their comeback tour. According to the magazine, Prince's return to the stage after a decade-long hiatus was a welcome one. The singer's 2004 tour grossed a staggering $90.3 million (approximately £48.5 million) in ticket sales, with 1.9 million copies of his latest album, Musicology, sold.

U2, the Irish rock band, have been honored at France's biggest music awards, but were beaten to a prize by Boyzone. U2 received a special achievement prize at the NRJ music awards, but Blue beat them to the international group award. Maroon 5 was named Best New International Artist, and took the Best International Song title for "This Love." More than five million radio listeners voted in the awards. The International Male and Female prizes went to Usher and Avril Lavigne respectively. Collecting his band's award from model Naomi Campbell at the Cannes ceremony, U2 frontman Bono said in French  "I'm not from this country, but I'll make a little confession to you - it's at the Côte d'Azur I feel at home."

Walmart fights back against false claims and criticism by launching advertising campaigns to "set the record straight" about its products and corporate behavior. The world's largest retailer, Walmart, has taken out more than 100 full-page advertisements in national newspapers. The company is seeking to dispel criticism over its pay deals, benefits package, and promotion strategy. Meanwhile, the drug company Eli Lilly is planning a campaign against "false" claims about its product Prozac. Walmart kicked off the battle with advertisements in newspapers like the Wall Street Journal, using an open letter from the company's president, Lee Scott, stating it was time for the public to hear the "unfiltered truth". "There are lots of 'urban legends' going around these days about Walmart, but facts are facts.

Tories outlining policing plans for local communities would be asked to go to the polls to elect their own area police commissioner, under plans unveiled by the Conservatives. Party leader Michael Howard said the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities. He stated that the new office would not supersede the job of a chief constable. The Lib Dems said the plan could let extreme groups run policing, while Labour criticised "extravagant" Tory promises on policing. Responding to the plans, the chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, which represents rank-and-file officers, said it was essential operational independence was retained. Jan Berry said  "It is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every time an election approaches. These plans could result in those with extreme political views dictating what actually happens on the ground.

At a glance  Tory health checks for UK opposition conservatives' plan to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan  individuals coming to live and work in Britain from outside the EU. If they plan to stay six months or more and are from a country with high TB rates, they would have to undergo a chest X-ray and further tests if necessary. All individuals from outside the European Union who want to stay a year or more will have to undergo a comprehensive medical examination, including tests for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive test for TB would automatically result in visa applications being rejected. All other conditions would be assessed on a case-by-case basis.

Doves soar to the top of the UK album chart, Manchester rock band Doves have debuted at number one with their new release, Some Cities. The trio displaces flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters at the top spot. The album follows the success of the single Black and White Town, which reached number six. R&B star Nelly has the new number one single with "Over and Over", which sees him team up with Tim McGraw. Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs all have new singles in the top ten, as do Futureheads and Usher. The latest Elvis Presley re-release, "(Marie's the Name)", his latest flame, entered the chart at number three, just one place ahead of Girls Aloud's "Wake Me Up". Hip-hop performer Akon's "Locked Up" is at number five, while hotly-tipped Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs have their second chart hit at number six with "Oh My God."

Davies is likely to remain with Gloucester, despite reported interest from the Ospreys, as he prefers to stay with the English side. According to BBC Wales, the Ospreys are interested in the 32-year-old, but Davies, one of the standout players in Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, is only on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. Having proved his value to the Zurich Premiership team, he is expected to receive a new deal next season. Davies' move to Gloucester came after the summer demise of the Celtic Warriors region left him without a team, forcing him to take a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. Although he received match time with the Ospreys at the request of the Wales management, Davies admitted before joining Gloucester that he was upset by his treatment at the time.

Cabinet anger at the prospect of using Whitehall cash to keep council tax bills down, local government ministers are unhappy about plans to allocate £512m from central government budgets in his pre-budget report on Thursday. Gordon Brown has reallocated the funds to support local authorities in England. Mr. Raynsford said he has had some "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans. He emphasized that local governments must deliver good services without significant council tax increases. The central government's £1bn package is part of an effort to help local authorities keep next year's council tax rises below 5% in what is likely to be a general election year. Mr. Raynsford noted that nearly all central government departments have an interest in well-run local authorities.

Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin, Israel's first Arab side to participate in a European competition, is set to face Newcastle United in the UEFA Cup, with four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, ready to take the field. Murambadoro, who gained recognition for his impressive performance at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, played a crucial role in Bnei Sakhnin's 6-1 victory over Albania's Partizani Tirana in the previous round. The goalkeeper recently joined the club after a brief stint with South Africa's Hellas FC. As the Israeli Cup champions, Bnei Sakhnin, based in Sakhnin, near Haifa, have a strong commitment to promoting peace and cooperation within Israel.

A new report suggests that reducing the drink-drive limit could save more lives than previously thought. According to a study by University College London, cutting the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would result in 65 lives saved annually. The findings are being published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety as MPs prepare to vote on the government's road safety bill. The bill includes changes to speeding fines, but not to the drink-drive limit. The research, conducted by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, also suggests that this move would lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on the UK's roads compared to 2003, resulting in estimated annual savings of £119m. A previous estimate, contained in a 1998 Department of Transport document, had suggested that such a move could save 50 lives a year.

This paper introduces a millimeter-scale CMOS 64x64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1x1 μm² diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512x512 μm². Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline. This eliminates the need for power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC is fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process and consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW under 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The functionality of the entire system is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam setting.

Controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that AVs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that aims to incentivize AVs to seek centrally controlled system-optimal routing by saving on tolls while user equilibrium-seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, in which dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, whereas the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering a mixed fleet of AVs and HVs.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, in quadrature squeezed states, and in entangled states of motion. The ability to coax larger and more tangible objects into a regime of quantum behavior has encouraged ideas for using mechanical oscillators in the processing and communication of quantum information and as precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the linear interaction between motion and light or electricity precludes access to the broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Early optomechanical proposals suggested the possibility of escaping this restriction by creating strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. Although there have been experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, these have not yet accessed non-classical states of motion.

Online reviews provide customers with product evaluations to inform their purchasing decisions. Unfortunately, these evaluations can be manipulated by professional spammers using fake reviews, also known as "spams," which have become increasingly sophisticated and cunning. Spammers have learned to adapt to deployed detectors, making it challenging to capture their tactics. These strategies can change rapidly over time, vary across different spammers and target products, and often remain unknown to most detectors. Moreover, most existing detectors prioritize detection accuracy, which is not necessarily aligned with the goal of maintaining the trustworthiness of product reviews. To address these challenges, we propose a minimax game where spammers and spam detectors compete with each other on their practical goals that are not solely focused on detection accuracy. The Nash equilibrium of this game leads to stable detectors that are agnostic to any mixed detection strategies.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer on a 3-level quantum system in lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we utilize the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. Among this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to control simultaneously the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define a measure of the robustness of an uh-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above 10^-4. The robustness of our shaped pulses is found superior to that of Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we examine the landscape of the negative log-likelihood function of Gaussian mixture models with a general number of components. Due to non-convexity, multiple local minima exist that are not globally optimal, even when the mixture is well-separated. We demonstrate that all local minima share the same form of structure, which partially identifies the component centers of the true mixture. Each local minimum involves a non-overlapping combination of fitting multiple Gaussian distributions to a single true component and fitting a single Gaussian to multiple true components. Our results apply to the setting where the true mixture components satisfy a certain separation condition, and are valid even when the number of components is over- or under-specified. For Gaussian mixtures with three components, we obtain sharper results in terms of the scaling between the components.

We consider the connection between the two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by a suitable subgroup g of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface x_m in the weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial w_m. The first, Berglund-Hübsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, uses another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface x_m^t inside it by a dual group g^t. In the second, Batyrev construction, the mirror partner is constructed as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide a simple evidence of the equivalence of these two constructions.

In this study, a generalization of the human gait was developed from existing models in the literature, including those of Keller and Kockshenev. In this hybrid model, a metabolic energy minimization strategy is combined with a non-linear description of the movement of the mass center's libration, aiming to reproduce the behavior of the walk-run transition. The results of the experimental data, for various speed regimes, suggest that the perimeter of the trajectory of the mass center is a crucial quantity in the quantification of this dynamic process. An experimental procedure was implemented in collaboration with the research group in biomedical engineering, basic sciences, and laboratories of the Universidad de Manuela Beltrán in Bogotá, Colombia.

We present a novel mixed-variable symplectic (mvs) integrator for planetary systems, which fully resolves close encounters. The method is based on a time regularization technique that preserves the stability properties of symplectic integrators while reducing the effective step size during close encounters between two planets. We employ a high-order mvs scheme, enabling the integration of large time steps far from close encounters. We demonstrate that this algorithm can resolve nearly exact collisions (i.e., with a mutual separation of a fraction of the physical radius) using the same time-step as in weakly perturbed problems, such as the solar system. We illustrate the long-term behavior of systems of six super-Earths experiencing strong scattering over 50 kyr. We compare our algorithm to hybrid methods, such as Mercury, and show that for an equivalent cost, we achieve much better energy conservation.

Entanglement is a crucial resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is the entanglement witness, which guarantees a positive measurement outcome for all separable states and can yield a negative result for certain entangled states. However, due to the exponentially increasing Hilbert-space dimension with respect to the system size, it is extremely challenging to construct an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states. For n-partite GHZ-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires n+1 local measurement settings and can tolerate up to 1/2 white noise. In comparison, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states requires only two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to 1/3 white noise.

In general relativity, the unique stationary solution for an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, which exhibits a distinctive multipolar structure dependent solely on its mass and spin. We develop a general method to extract the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a large family of horizonless microstate geometries. The latter can break the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric and exhibit a much richer multipolar structure, providing a portal to constrain fuzzball models phenomenologically. We find numerical evidence that all multipole moments are typically larger (in absolute value) than those of a Kerr black hole with the same mass and spin. Current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates impose only mild constraints on fuzzballs, while future gravitational-wave detections of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the space mission LISA will improve these bounds by orders of magnitude.

Reasoning about graphs evolving over time is a challenging concept in many domains, such as bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. We consider a common case in which edges can be short-term interactions (e.g., messaging) or long-term structural connections (e.g., friendship). In practice, long-term edges are often specified by humans. Human-specified edges can be both costly to produce and suboptimal for the downstream task. To alleviate these issues, we propose a model based on temporal point processes and variational autoencoders that learns to infer temporal attention between nodes by observing node communication. As temporal attention drives between-node feature propagation, using the dynamics of node interactions to learn this key component provides more flexibility while simultaneously avoiding issues associated with human-specified edges.

Observations of thermally driven transverse vibrations of a photonic crystal waveguide (PCW) are reported. The PCW consists of two parallel nanobeams with a 240 nm vacuum gap between the beams. Models are developed and validated for the transduction of beam motion to phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating in a guided mode of the PCW for probe frequencies both far from and near the dielectric band edge. Since our PCW has been designed for near-field atom trapping, this research provides a foundation for evaluating the potential detrimental effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near the surfaces of PCWs. Long-term goals are to achieve strong atom-mediated links between individual phonons of vibration and single photons propagating in the guided modes of the PCW, thereby enabling optomechanics at the quantum level with atoms, photons, and phonons.

We establish natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. In particular, the restriction homomorphisms between the orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups of adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. The interest in the splitting stems from equivariant stable homotopy theory. The equivariant stable homotopy groups of every global spectrum form a global Mackey functor, so the splittings imply that certain long exact homotopy group sequences split into short exact sequences. For the real and complex global Thom spectra $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$, the splittings imply the regularity of various Euler classes related to the tautological representations of $o(n)$ and $u(n)$.

Baryonic feedback effects lead to a suppression of the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The poorly constrained shape and amplitude of this suppression are an important source of uncertainties for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys, such as Euclid or LSST. In this, our first paper in a series of two, we use simulations to build a Euclid-like tomographic mock data-set for the cosmic shear power spectrum and the corresponding covariance matrix, which are both corrected for baryonic effects following the baryonification method of Schneider et al. (2019). Additionally, we develop an emulator to obtain fast predictions of the baryonic power suppression, allowing us to perform a likelihood inference analysis for a standard LCDM cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

In real-world settings, such as child-centered recordings, spontaneous conversations have been found to be particularly challenging to process. This is because they involve a wide variety of conditions, including different speakers, noise levels, and recording devices. However, building speech processing models that can handle such a diverse range of conditions would be highly valuable for language acquisition studies, where researchers seek to quantify and qualify the speech children hear and produce, as well as for early diagnosis and evaluating the effectiveness of remediation. In this paper, we present our approach to designing an open-source neural network to classify audio segments into vocalizations produced by children wearing the recording device, vocalizations produced by other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. Our diverse child-centered corpora, totaling 260 hours of recordings across 10 languages, serve as the foundation for this endeavor.

Density-based clustering relies on the concept of linking groups to specific features of the probability distribution underlying the data. By referencing a true, yet unknown, population structure, we frame the clustering problem in a standard inferential setting, where the concept of ideal population clustering is defined as the partition induced by the true density function. Nonparametric modal clustering formulation draws a correspondence between groups and domains of attraction of density modes. Operationally, a nonparametric density estimate is required, and a proper selection of the amount of smoothing, governing the shape of the density and hence possibly the modal structure, is crucial to identify the final partition. In this work, we address the issue of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic perspective.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC are sensitive to the interference between the standard model and higher-dimensional operators, parameterizing the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for the diboson scattering amplitudes set an obstacle to the naive interference contributions of dimension-six operators, causing the total diboson rate correction's leading contribution to cancel. In this case, carefully measuring the azimuthal decay angles "resurrects" the interference, recouping sensitivity to the "non-interfering" operators. We explore these signatures in detail, and find that the EFT uncertainties associated with higher-dimensional operators are uniquely well-suppressed by the construction of an asymmetry variable which is only generated by these non-interfering operators, relegating the effects of higher-dimensional, interfering operators to the same status as statistical errors in this observable.

Causal inference from observational data is a primary goal of many data analyses in the health and social sciences. However, academic statistics has often been critical of data analyses with a causal objective. The introduction of the term 'data science' provides a historic opportunity to redefine data analysis in a way that naturally accommodates causal inference from observational data. Like others before, we categorize the scientific contributions of data science into three classes of tasks  description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction (which includes causal inference). A clear classification of data science tasks is necessary to discuss the data, assumptions, and analytics required to successfully accomplish each task. We argue that a failure to adequately describe the role of subject-matter expert knowledge in data analysis is a common source of widespread misunderstandings about data science.

The weak gravity conjecture demands the existence of superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. The standard lore is that these particles are introduced to ensure that extremal black holes are either unstable or marginally stable, but it remains unclear what would happen if this doesn't occur. This note shows that, for a generic Einstein-quantum theory of gravity in AdS, the stability of extremal black branes is in tension with rigorously proven quantum information theorems about entanglement entropy. Avoiding this contradiction leads to a non-perturbative version of the weak gravity conjecture, which reduces to the usual statement at weak coupling. The argument is general and does not rely on either supersymmetry or a particular UV completion, assuming only the validity of Einsteinian gravity, effective field theory, and holography.

Understanding how strongly correlated two-dimensional (2D) systems can give rise to unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures is a major unsolved problem in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2D Fermi gases have emerged as clean and controllable model systems to study the interplay of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, but direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been lacking. Here, we demonstrate superfluidity in an ultracold 2D Fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and observing no dissipation below a critical velocity vc. We measure vc as a function of interaction strength and find a maximum in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. Our measurement establishes ultracold Fermi gases as a powerful tool for studying the influence of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids.

The ordinary differential equation (ODE) is a mathematical model widely used in various application domains, including climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering, due to its intuitive ability to model complex phenomena. Despite the widespread use of ODEs in modeling, the frequent absence of their analytical solutions makes it challenging to estimate ODE parameters from the data, particularly when the model has a large number of variables and parameters. This paper proposes a Bayesian ODE parameter estimation algorithm that is fast and accurate, even for models with numerous parameters. The proposed method approximates an ODE model with a state-space model based on equations of a numerical solver, enabling fast estimation by avoiding the computation of a complete numerical solution in the likelihood. The posterior is obtained through a variational Bayes method, specifically, the approximate Riemannian conjugate gradient method (Honkela et al.

We study the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in NSN junctions formed by a time-reversal symmetry-breaking Weyl semimetal (WSM) in proximity to an S-wave superconductor. We find that the differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes strongly depend on the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. We identify the influence of a chiral chemical potential, i.e., the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality, on the transport characteristics of the junction. Notably, we observe a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs generated via Andreev reflection in the two WSM regions. The spin polarization is opposite in the two WSM regions and highly sensitive to the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics has been shown to be an effective and controllable technique for tailoring the surface electrical conductivity of ceramic pieces, and this approach has been employed in a number of applications. Notably, it enables grading the voltage drop across high-voltage insulators, thereby increasing the maximum operational voltage that can be applied across the insulator without surface flashover. However, a concern for the use of the method is the long-term stability of the implantation-induced conductivity, particularly if the implanted metal species is readily oxidized. Here, we report on our examination of the long-term behavior of the surface conductivity of titanium-implanted alumina. The results indicate that, after an initial drop of up to 40% in the first few weeks after implantation, the conductivity exhibits only a very slow decrease of approximately 10% over the following year.

We introduce a novel, Skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, rooted in the concept of hidden local symmetry. The associated charge is equivalent to the skyrmion charge for any smooth configuration. Moreover, there exist singular configurations that can be identified as n_f=1 baryons, charged under the new symmetry. Under this identification, the vector mesons play the role of Chern-Simons vector fields living on the quantum Hall droplet that forms the n_f=1 baryon. We propose that this current is the correct effective expression for the baryon current at low energies. This proposal yields a unified picture for the two types of baryons, enabling them to continuously transform into one another in a natural manner. Furthermore, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be interpreted as a consequence of Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions presents an intriguing opportunity to combine anomalous Hall and Josephson physics within a single device. We theoretically investigate how the superposition of both effects influences the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. The transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface generates sizable transverse Hall supercurrents, which we refer to as anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. We generalize the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, initially established to quantify usual tunneling Josephson current flows, to evaluate the transverse current components and demonstrate that their amplitudes are widely adjustable via the spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. As a distinct spectroscopic fingerprint of Josephson junctions, well-localized subgap bound states form around the interface.

Following the suggestion from Monte Carlo experiments by Jimenez et al. (2020), which highlight the importance of dipoles in the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence, it is found that the kinetic energy of this flow is carried by elongated streams formed by the concatenation of dipoles. Vortices separate into two families  one consisting of small, fast-moving cores and another of larger, slowly moving ones, which can be described as 'frozen' into a slowly evolving 'crystal'. The kinematics of both families are distinct, with the former exhibiting self-similarity. The latter is responsible for most of the kinetic energy of the flow, and its vortices form the dipoles and the streams. Mechanisms are discussed for the growth of this slow-moving component.

Continuous-time quantum walks have been proven to be an extremely valuable framework for designing several quantum algorithms. The running time of quantum algorithms in this framework is often characterized by the quantum hitting time, which is the time required by the quantum walk to find a vertex of interest with a high probability. In this article, we present improved upper bounds for the quantum hitting time that can be applied to several continuous-time quantum walk-based quantum algorithms. In particular, we apply our techniques to the glued-trees problem, significantly improving their hitting time upper bound, reducing it from O(n^5) to O(n^2 log n). Moreover, our methods also help to exponentially improve the dependence on precision of the continuous-time quantum walk-based algorithm to find a marked node on any ergodic, reversible Markov chain, as per Chakraborty et al.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be classified as dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or the "loss-cone") EMRIs, previously considered as the main EMRI sources for the laser interferometer space antenna, are primarily produced by multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. This letter highlights an alternative EMRI formation channel  wet EMRI formation assisted by the accretion flow around accreting galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). In this channel, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes that are initially moving on inclined orbits, and subsequently drives them to migrate towards the MBH - this process boosts the formation rate of EMRIs in such galaxies by orders of magnitude.

When a new user signs up on a website, we typically have limited information about them - no interaction with items, no user profile, and no social links with other users. Under such circumstances, we still expect our recommender systems to attract users at the first time so that the users decide to stay on the website and become active users. This problem falls into the new user cold-start category, and it is crucial to the development and even survival of a company. Existing works on user cold-start recommendation often require additional user efforts, for instance, setting up an interview process, or making use of side information, such as user demographics, locations, social relations, etc. However, users may not be willing to take the interview and side information on cold-start users is usually not available.

Deep learning has successfully addressed numerous problems that were previously out of reach of heuristic algorithms. It has also been successfully applied in wireless communications, even in well-understood and optimized radio systems, where some gains have been achieved by learning individual parts of a receiver. However, a better approach is to jointly learn the entire receiver. This often results in a challenging nonlinear problem, for which the optimal solution is infeasible to implement. To address this challenge, we propose a deep, fully convolutional neural network, deeprx, which executes the entire receiver pipeline from frequency domain signal stream to uncoded bits in a 5G-compliant manner. We facilitate accurate channel estimation by constructing the input of the convolutional neural network in a very specific manner using both the data and pilot symbols.

Mutation-based fuzzing typically employs an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs, known as a corpus, from which to generate new inputs by mutation. A corpus of potential seeds often contains thousands of similar inputs. The lack of diversity in this corpus can lead to inefficient fuzzing efforts due to exhaustive mutation from all available seeds. To address this, fuzzers come equipped with distillation tools, such as afl-cmin, that select the smallest subset of seeds that trigger the same range of instrumentation data points as the full corpus. It is commonly suggested that minimizing the number and cumulative size of the seeds leads to more efficient fuzzing, which we explore systematically. Our results show the impact of five distillation approaches on finding bugs in real-world software after 34 CPU-years of fuzzing.

In this paper, we investigate multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observation. The agents can be grouped into several categories, each of which has similar state transition structures, and can thus be relabeled into the same template. Based on this template, a scalable supervisor with a state size and computational cost independent of the number of agents is designed for the case of partial observation. The scalable supervisor under partial observation does not need to be recomputed regardless of how many agents are added to or removed from the system. We generalize our earlier results to partial observation by proposing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the scalable least restrictive supervisor on the template level. An example is provided to illustrate the proposed scalable supervisory synthesis.

Electric network frequency fluctuations constitute a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient approach for ENF estimation is introduced, utilizing a novel temporal windowing strategy based on the filter-bank capon spectral estimator. A type of Goerg-Semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix is employed due to the Toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix. Moreover, this approach innovatively applies a non-rectangular temporal window, at the stage preceding spectral estimation, a departure from traditional rectangular windowing. Krylov matrices are leveraged for rapid implementation of matrix inversions. The proposed approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in ENF estimation, when a short time window of 1 second is employed in power recordings. In speech recordings, the proposed approach yields highly accurate results with respect to both time complexity and accuracy.

The direpack package aims to establish a set of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques within the Python universe as a single, consistent package. The dimension reduction methods included resort into three categories  projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators for dimension reduction. As a corollary, regularized regression estimators based on these reduced dimension spaces are provided as well, ranging from classical principal component regression to sparse partial robust M regression. The package also contains a set of classical and robust pre-processing utilities, including generalized spatial signs, as well as dedicated plotting functionality and cross-validation utilities. Finally, direpack has been written consistently with the scikit-learn API, such that the estimators can seamlessly be integrated into (statistical and/or machine) learning pipelines within that framework.

The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been widely applied for high-resolution optical imaging. We investigated the fluorescence anomalous saturation effect of nitrogen vacancy defects in diamond, using high-power laser excitation. This increased the nonlinearity of the fluorescence emission and altered the spatial frequency distribution of the fluorescence image. We employed a differential excitation protocol to extract high spatial frequency information. By modulating the excitation laser's power, we achieved an approximate 1.6-fold improvement in spatial resolution compared to confocal microscopy. Due to the simplicity of the experimental setup and data processing, we expect this method can be used to improve the spatial resolution of sensing and biological labeling with defects in solids.

When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, the conventional approach of using individual survey weights, constructed to be inversely proportional to the unit survey inclusion probabilities, to form a pseudo-likelihood no longer yields asymptotically unbiased inference. We develop a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that achieves unbiased inference for generating hyperparameters of the random effects. We contrast our approach with frequentist methods that rely on numerical integration, revealing that only the Bayesian method achieves both unbiased estimation with respect to the sampling design distribution and consistency with respect to the population generating distribution. Our simulations and real-data example for a survey of business establishments demonstrate the utility of our approach across different modeling formulations and sampling designs. This work serves as a capstone for recent developmental efforts that combine traditional survey estimation approaches with the Bayesian modeling paradigm, providing a bridge across the two rich but disparate subfields.

Low-symmetry 2D materials, such as res$_2$ and rese$_2$ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, borophene, and others, exhibit more intricate atomistic structures than the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. The reduced symmetries of these emerging materials give rise to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, as well as entirely new properties, including ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, large nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. Novel electronic topological properties, nonlinear elastic properties, and structural phase transformations can also occur due to low symmetry. The "Beyond Graphene  Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials" special topic was assembled to highlight recent experimental and theoretical research on these emerging materials.

The orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups were studied using the Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, it was found that in a mesogenic polymer, in contrast to low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of the electric birefringence of a melt above the temperature of the nematic-isotropic phase transition can be represented by a sum of several exponential processes, two of which play a decisive role. These main processes replace each other in a temperature range of approximately 50 degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy also enabled the distinction of two processes of orientational relaxation  the first is attributed to the rotation of the side mesogenic groups, and the second is associated with the motion of the main chain segments.

Deep hashing methods have demonstrated exceptional retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval. Optimizing discrete hash bits is consistently the primary focus in deep hashing methods. A common approach in these methods is to adopt an activation function, for instance, the sigmoid or tanh function, and minimize a quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this paradigm may result in more and more hash bits becoming stuck in the saturated area of the activation functions and failing to escape. We refer to this issue as the "dead bits problem." Moreover, the existing quantization loss exacerbates this issue as well. In this paper, we propose a simple yet effective gradient amplifier that acts before activation functions to mitigate the dead bits problem.

We investigate the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero triplet scalar, motivated by two-step electroweak symmetry-breaking. We consider both the possibility that the triplets are stable and contribute to the dark matter density, or that they decay via mixing with the standard model Higgs boson. The former is constrained by disappearing charged track searches at the LHC and by dark matter direct detection experiments, while the latter is constrained by existing multilepton collider searches. We find that a two-step electroweak phase transition involving a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is ruled out by direct detection searches, while an unstable triplet with a mass less than 230 GeV is excluded at 95% confidence level.

This study shows that the eccentric debris rings around the stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than expected in the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario, also known as the pericenter glow. The standard scenario assumes an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis a, whose eccentricity is increased to ef after the gas disc has dispersed due to secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, resulting in a belt of width 2ae_f. A minor modification to this scenario suggests that narrower belts can arise if the planetesimals are initially eccentric, which could result from earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. Alternatively, a primordial eccentricity could be caused by instabilities that increase the disc eccentricity, without the need for any planets.

An electron is typically considered to possess only one type of kinetic energy, but could it have more, due to its spin and charge, or by exciting other electrons? In one dimension, the physics of interacting electrons is well-captured at low energies by the Tomonaga-Luttinger-Liquid (TLL) model, yet little has been observed experimentally beyond this linear regime. Here, we report on measurements of many-body modes in 1D gated-wires using a tunnelling spectroscopy technique. We observe two separate Fermi seas at high energies, associated with spin and charge excitations, together with the emergence of three additional 1D'replica' modes that strengthen with decreasing wire length. The effective interaction strength in the wires is varied by changing the amount of 1D inter-subband screening by over 45%.

The assembly history of the Milky Way is currently being unveiled, thanks to the data provided by the Gaia mission. It is likely that the globular cluster system of our galaxy has followed a similarly intricate formation path. To constrain this formation path, we explore the link between the globular clusters and the known merging events that the Milky Way has experienced. To this end, we combined the kinematic information provided by Gaia for almost all galactic clusters, with the largest sample of cluster ages available after carefully correcting for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin, we analyzed their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integral motion. The results show that about 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.

The estimation of the intrinsic dimension of a dataset is a fundamental step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article presents an R package called intrinsic, which implements novel state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators for the intrinsic dimension of a dataset. The package includes several high-level, intuitive functions that rely on a comprehensive set of efficient, low-level routines. The intrinsic dimension estimators in this package fall into two categories  homogeneous and heterogeneous models. The functions dedicated to these two methods perform inference under both frequentist and Bayesian frameworks. The package also includes the hidalgo model, a Bayesian mixture model, for which an efficient Gibbs sampler is implemented.

Spintronic nanodevices have ultra-fast, nonlinear dynamic, and recurrent behaviors on a nanosecond scale, promising to enable spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. Two physical RC systems based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOS) were proposed and modeled to process image classification tasks and nonlinear dynamic system prediction, respectively. Based on our micromagnetic simulation results on the nonlinear responses of MSM and STNOS with current pulse stimulation, the handwritten digits recognition task demonstrates that an RC system using one single MSM has outstanding performance on image classification. Additionally, complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems can also be well solved by a physical RC system consisting of 24 STNOS confirmed in a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10 tasks.

Ranking algorithms play a crucial role in online platforms, from search engines to recommender systems. In this paper, we uncover a surprising consequence of popularity-based rankings  the fewer the items reporting a given signal, the higher the share of the overall traffic they collectively attract. This few-get-richer effect arises in settings where there are few distinct classes of items (e.g., left-leaning news sources versus right-leaning news sources), and items are ranked based on their popularity. We demonstrate analytically that the few-get-richer effect emerges when people tend to click on top-ranked items and have heterogeneous preferences for the classes of items. Using simulations, we examine how the strength of the effect changes with assumptions about the setting and human behavior. We also test our predictions experimentally in an online experiment with human participants. Our findings have significant implications for understanding the spread of misinformation.

Weight pruning has been widely recognized as a straightforward and effective method for eliminating redundancy in deep neural networks, thereby achieving acceleration on various platforms. However, most pruning techniques are essentially trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity, which can lead to impaired inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration performance. To address this issue, we introduce a novel sparsity dimension, namely pattern-based sparsity, which encompasses pattern and connectivity sparsity, and is both highly accurate and hardware-friendly. With carefully designed patterns, our proposed pruning method consistently achieves accuracy enhancement and better feature extraction ability on various dnn structures and datasets, and our pattern-aware pruning framework also enables pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern and connectivity pruning, and weight training simultaneously. Our approach naturally fits into compiler optimization for highly efficient dnn execution on mobile platforms.

Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that differs significantly from a treated group is susceptible to bias from historical events that have different effects on the groups. Constructing a more closely matched control group by matching a subset of the overall control group to the treated group may result in reduced bias. We examine this phenomenon in simulation studies. We investigate the effect of mountaintop removal mining (MRM) on mortality using a difference-in-differences analysis that takes advantage of the increase in MRM following the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments. For a difference-in-differences analysis of the effect of MRM on mortality, we constructed a more closely matched control group and found a 95% confidence interval that contains substantial adverse effects alongside no effect and small beneficial effects.

When constructing models to summarize clinical data for use in simulations, it is good practice to evaluate the models for their ability to reproduce the data. This can be achieved by means of visual predictive checks (VPCs), which consist of (1) several reproductions of the original study by simulation from the model under evaluation, (2) calculating estimates of interest for each simulated study and (3) comparing the distribution of those estimates with the estimate from the original study. This is a straightforward method that can be applied generally. Here, we consider the application of the method to time-to-event data and examine the special case when a time-varying covariate is not known or cannot be approximated after event time.

Novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling an open quantum system via sequential schemes are showcased. We discuss how similar protocols, relying on both repeated quantum measurements and dynamic decoupling control pulses, can enable  (i) confining and protecting quantum dynamics in accordance with the zero-point physics. (ii) analytically predicting the probability that a quantum system is transferred into a target quantum state by means of stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) optimally reconstructing the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing in the frequency domain the filter functions driving the designed quantum sensor. The achievement of these tasks will enhance our ability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thus bringing advances to quantum science and technologies.

Palm-sweaty, heart racing, stomach in knots. You can't cry for help. Not only is your throat too tight to breathe, but it'd be so embarrassing. No, you're not being stalked by a monster, you're speaking in public, a fate some deem worse than death. See, when you're dead, you feel nothing; at a podium, you feel stage fright. But at some point, we've all had to communicate in front of people, so you have to try and overcome it. To start, understanding what stage fright is. Humans, as social animals that we are, are wired to worry about reputation. Public speaking can threaten it. Before a speech, you fret, 'What if people think I'm awful and I'm an idiot?'

I can't think of anyone who has only one interest in life, and that's all they want to do for the rest of their life. Around 15% of American workers don't have traditional full-time jobs; they're half-time, part-time, contract workers, or temps. The term "side hustle" seems to fit with this ethos, where people are piecing together a few different things to make a living. The word "side hustle" has its roots in popular African American newspapers, dating back to the 1920s. In those days, these papers used the word "hustle" to refer to some kind of scam. By the 1950s, they were using "side hustle" to refer to legitimate work, too. A side hustle is distinct from a second job, as it's not necessarily about necessity, but rather about making extra income or pursuing a passion.

Two twin domains, two radically opposing design philosophies. One is composed of thousands of steel components, the other of a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. One is imposed upon the environment, the other creates it. One is designed for nature, the other is designed by human hands. Michelangelo once said that when he gazed upon raw marble, he saw a figure struggling to be free. The chisel was his only tool. However, living things are not chiseled. They grow. And in our smallest units of life, our cells, we carry all the information necessary for every other cell to function and to replicate. Tools also have consequences. At least since the Industrial Revolution, the world of design has been dominated by the rigors of manufacturing and mass production.

Hello. My name is Simone. You know how people tell you if you get nervous when you're on stage, picturing people in the audience naked? It's like it's this thing that's supposed to make you feel better. But I was thinking - picturing all of you naked in 2018 feels kind of weird and wrong. Like, we're working really hard on moving past things like that, so we need a new method of dealing with if you get nervous on stage. Sustainability represents the essence, location, and method of what is caught. The who and the why behind it are what's crucial to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices. I want to know how I impact them. I want to know how they impact me. I want to know why they fish. I want to know how they rely on the ocean's bounty for their survival. Where sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative is the ability to replenish and progress.

I'd like to share with you the fascinating story of the future of money. Let's begin by exploring the culture of the Yap, a society that thrived in Micronesia during the early 1900s. The Yap, with their unique form of currency, use limestone discs called Rai stones. Unlike our coins, these Rai stones are not exchanged or moved around, as they can become quite massive. The largest Rai stone is approximately four tons and 12 feet across. To keep track of ownership, the Yap simply keep a record of who possesses a portion of the stone. There's a remarkable story about a group of sailors who were transporting a stone across the ocean when they encountered some difficulties, and the stone ended up falling into the sea.

You've been accused of a crime you didn't commit, and it's impossible to prove your innocence. If you insist on maintaining your innocence, you'll likely be found guilty and executed. However, if you confess, apologize, and implicate others, you'll be set free. This was the daunting choice facing those accused of witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693. They were the victims of a mix of paranoia about the supernatural, misdirected religious fervor, and a justice system that prioritized repentance over truth. Salem was settled in 1626 by the Puritans, a group of English Protestants. Life was strict and isolated for the people of Salem, marked by frequent battles with their Native American neighbors and rival groups of French settlers.

There are hundreds of thousands of people on transplant waiting lists, waiting for critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could save their lives. Unfortunately, there aren't nearly enough donor organs available to meet that demand. What if, instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? That's the idea behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine currently under development. We're not yet able to print complex organs just yet, but simpler tissues, including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange, are already within our grasp. Bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3D printing, a technique that deposits layers of material on top of each other to construct a three-dimensional object, one slice at a time.

I didn't always make my living from music. For about five years after graduating from an esteemed liberal arts university, this was my day job. On October 4, 1957, the world witnessed a historic moment of awe and trepidation as the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, the world's first artificial satellite, into space. This small, two-foot-diameter metal sphere sparked a space race between the United States and the Soviet Union that would last for eighteen years and profoundly alter the world as we know it. Although Sputnik was not the first human-made object to enter space, that distinction belongs to the V-2 rocket, developed by Germany during World War II for missile attacks on Allied cities. While the V-2 rocket was not particularly effective, the end of the war saw both the United States and the Soviet Union capture the technology and the scientists behind it, subsequently incorporating it into their own projects.

Menstruation  a natural biological process, shrouded in centuries of stigma, is often whispered about. But why? As I speak to you now, over 800 million women worldwide are experiencing it. The world's largest and most significant environmental and industrial project is situated in the heart of the largest and most intact forest in the world, Canada's boreal forest. In 1903, President Theodore Roosevelt embarked on a three-day camping trip in California's Yosemite Valley. He slept among towering sequoia trees, braved a snowstorm, and spent hours conversing around the campfire with his host and guide, conservationist John Muir. Roosevelt was an avid outdoorsman, but Muir had invited him to Yosemite for more than just camping  the valley was in danger. Although Yosemite had been protected land since 1864, it was still at risk of overdevelopment in 1903. The battle to set aside land for both preservation and public use had been ongoing for decades, a challenge that proved easier said than done. The struggle began with the 1849 gold rush, when miners flooded westward, seeking gold in the Sierra Nevada foothills.

Imagine if you could plug your brain into a machine that would bring you ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If you were given the choice to sign up for that kind of existence, would you? That's the question philosopher Robert Nozick posed through a thought experiment he called the Experience Machine. The experiment asks us to consider a world in which scientists have developed a machine that would simulate real life, guaranteeing experiences of only pleasure and never pain. The catch  you would have to permanently leave reality behind, but you'd hardly know the difference. Your experiences would be indistinguishable from reality. Life's natural ups and downs would be replaced with an endless series of ups, and sounds like a rather enticing prospect.

During our consultation, she inquired about whether medical marijuana might alleviate her symptoms. I reflected on everything I had learned in medical school, which didn't take long because I had learned absolutely nothing about medical marijuana.

For the past 24 years, I have been a firefighter in Huntington, West Virginia. As a firefighter, my team and I are tasked with saving lives and property from disasters such as car wrecks, house fires, and life-threatening medical emergencies. As a woman leading a department in a male-dominated profession, I decided 10 years ago to increase my medical knowledge and received a nursing degree. It became clear that the next big threat facing not only my city, but other cities around the country, was not a one-and-done disaster, where you can ride in like the cavalry, put out the fire and leave, feeling like you've made a difference and everything is okay.

Where does all the carbon we release go? Carbon plays a crucial role in a natural cycle, present in all living things  in the soil, in the oceans, in the atmosphere, and in rocks deep underground. When plants and other living organisms die, much of their stored carbon is released back to the atmosphere, where it is absorbed by new plants and other organisms. However, over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock, while some becomes fossil fuels  coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions also release some of the carbon trapped in rock. Furthermore, human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, also release a significant amount of prehistoric carbon. Today, humans release approximately 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.

Even nature's most reviled creatures harbor important secrets, but who wouldn't want to avoid a swarm of cockroaches approaching? One of the most significant differences between natural and human technologies lies in robustness. Robust systems remain stable in complex and unfamiliar environments. Notably, cockroaches can self-stabilize when running over rough terrain. When we attached a jet pack to them or subjected them to a perturbation like an earthquake, we found that their exquisitely tuned legs enable them to self-stabilize without engaging their brainpower. They can traverse complex terrain like grass effortlessly, without becoming destabilized. We discovered a new behavior where, due to their shape, they naturally roll onto their side to navigate this artificial grass test. Robust systems can perform multiple tasks with the same underlying structure. We've recently discovered a new behavior that illustrates this capability.

What is a parent? It's not an easy question. Today, we have adoption, stepfamilies, and surrogate mothers. Many parents face tough questions and tough decisions. Should we tell our child about the sperm donation? If so, when? What words to use? Sperm donors are often referred to as "biological fathers," but should we really be using the word "father"? When I look in the mirror today, I see a justice and education scholar at Columbia University, a youth mentor, an activist, and a future New York State Senator. We need to build a weather service for water. However, until we collectively demand accountability, the incentives to fund it will not exist.
